SEARCH
Package org.example

Class TextParser

java.lang.Object
org.example.TextParser
public class TextParser extends Object
A parser that converts a raw string into a structured Text object. It uses a stateful approach to build sentences and words character by character. This class is designed to be reusable but is not thread-safe.

  • Field Summary

    Modifier and Type
    Field
    Description
    private List<Sentence>
    allSentences
    Stores all completed sentences found during parsing.
    private List<SentenceElement>
    currentSentenceElements
    Stores SentenceElement objects for the sentence currently being built.
    private StringBuilder
    currentWordBuilder
    Accumulates characters to form the word currently being built.

  • Field Details

    • allSentences

      Stores all completed sentences found during parsing.

    • currentSentenceElements

      Stores SentenceElement objects for the sentence currently being built.

      private StringBuilder currentWordBuilder
      Accumulates characters to form the word currently being built.

  • Constructor Details

    • TextParser

      public TextParser()

  • Method Details

    • parse

      public Text parse(String rawText)
      Parses a raw string into a structured Text object. This is the main entry point. The method first normalizes the input text, then processes it character by character to build a hierarchical model of the text.
      Parameters:
      rawText - The input string to parse.
      Returns:
      A Text object representing the structured content of the input string.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the rawText is null or empty.

    • normalizeText

      private String normalizeText(String text)
      Normalizes the input string by trimming leading/trailing whitespace and replacing any sequence of tabs and spaces with a single space.
      Parameters:
      text - The raw text string.
      Returns:
      A clean, normalized string ready for parsing.

    • processCharacter

      private void processCharacter(char currentChar)
      Processes a single character from the text. It determines if the character is part of a word and delegates to the appropriate handler method.
      Parameters:
      currentChar - The character to process.

    • handleNonWordCharacter

      private void handleNonWordCharacter(char currentChar)
      Handles a character that is not a part of a word (e.g., punctuation or space). This method first flushes any pending word, then adds the punctuation mark, and finally checks if this mark terminates the current sentence.
      Parameters:
      currentChar - The non-word character to handle.

    • flushWord

      private void flushWord()
      Checks if a word is currently being built in currentWordBuilder. If so, it creates a new Word object, adds it to the current sentence's elements, and resets the builder to start a new word.

    • flushSentence

      private void flushSentence()
      Checks if the current sentence has any elements. If so, it creates a new Sentence object, adds it to the main list of sentences, and resets the list of elements to begin a new sentence.

    • addRemainingElements

      private void addRemainingElements()
      A cleanup method called after the main parsing loop finishes. It ensures that any remaining word or sentence that wasn't terminated by punctuation is properly saved to the text structure.

    • isWordCharacter

      private boolean isWordCharacter(char currentChar)
      Utility method to check if a character is considered part of a word. In this context, a word character is a letter, a digit, or an apostrophe.
      Parameters:
      currentChar - The character to check.
      Returns:
      true if the character is part of a word, false otherwise.

    • isSentenceTerminator

      private boolean isSentenceTerminator(char currentChar)
      Utility method to check if a character is a sentence terminator.
      Parameters:
      currentChar - The character to check.
      Returns:
      true if the character is a period, exclamation mark, or question mark.
